Hi David,

In my experience, these two cases are usually equivalent so the =
distinction
doesn't provide much value.  What's the point of declaring that=
 b() depends
on a() if b() doesn't need any state created by a()?  By doing=
 this, you are
causing your test run to needlessly take longer if you are r=
unning in
parallel (since b() can't be run until after a() has completed, w=
hile it
could be run in parallel if you didn't declare that dependency).

I=
'm going to think more about this and see if I can find a counter example
t=
o prove my impression wrong.
